questions.text: In a recent census survey conducted in a developing country, the government aims to measure the literacy levels among its population accurately. The survey team decides to calculate both the crude literacy rate and the effective literacy rate to gain a comprehensive understanding. What distinguishes the effective literacy rate from the crude literacy rate?

options.label: A
options.text: It provides a broad measure of literacy across all age groups.

options.label: B
options.text: It focuses on the population aged 7 years and above.

options.label: C
options.text: The literacy rate is calculated using the total population as the denominator.

questions.correct_answer: B. It focuses on the population aged 7 years and above.
questions.explanation:
Crude Literacy Rate

Effective Literacy Rate

Definition: The literacy rate is calculated using the total population as the denominator. (Option C)

Definition: The literacy rate is calculated using the population aged 7 years and above as the denominator.

Includes the entire population. (Option D)

Focuses on the population aged 7 years and above.

Provides a broad measure of literacy across all age groups. (Option A)

Offers a more specific measure of literacy among individuals more likely to have completed basic education.

options.label: D
options.text: Methods used for termination of pregnancy

questions.text: According to the system, which has the logo below and under the Central Birth and Death Registration Act, 1969, what is the time limit for registering for birth and death events in India?
Which of the following statements are true regarding the Sample registration system?

options.label: A
options.text: An independent survey is conducted by an investigator-supervisor every 6 months.

options.label: B
options.text: Key data components of SRS are the number of births and death

options.label: C
options.text: An enumerator continuously keeps track of the birth and death count

questions.text: Which of the following data components are provided by the census? Population size and distribution HIV status and reproductive health status Education and employment status Nutritional status
What does the De facto method of data collection refer to?

options.label: A
options.text: Information is collected only from a certain subset of the population.

options.label: B
options.text: Information is based on where people are found during the census.

options.label: C
options.text: Information is based on the individual's legal proof of permanent residency.

options.label: D
options.text: Information is only from institutional households.

questions.correct_answer: B. Information is based on where people are found during the census.
questions.explanation:
De facto method

De jure method

Description
  • This refers to collecting information based on the people's current location at the time of the survey.
  • This method was used in the Indian Census only up to the 1930s
  • This refers to the collection of information based on the individual's legal proof of permanent residency, regardless of where they stay during the survey.
  • The Indian census survey currently uses this method.

Example

A legal resident of New Delhi may be living and working in Mumbai during the census; thus, if the de facto method is used, his data will be collected during the Mumbai census survey.

A legal resident of New Delhi may be living and working in Mumbai during the census; thus, if the de jure method is used, his data will be collected during the New Delhi census survey.

questions.text: Which of the following is also known as the final impact indicator in the National family planning program?
Which of the following indicators helps to achieve the target of the national family planning program?
Which of the following is NOT true regarding the Net reproductive rate (NRR)?

options.label: B
options.text: Defined as the no. of daughters or girls a newborn girl will bear or will have throughout her reproductive lifespan, considering the current age-specific fertility patterns and mortality rates

options.label: C
options.text: The most sensitive indicator to evaluate the National family planning program

questions.correct_answer: A. Indicator of complete family size
questions.explanation:
Net reproductive rate (NRR)

Definition

NRR is the number of daughters or girls a newborn will bear or have throughout her reproductive lifespan, considering the current age-specific fertility patterns and mortality rates. (Option B)

Interpretation

  • It is the most sensitive indicator to evaluate National family planning program (Option C)
  • It is a mortality-dependent fertility indicator. (Option D)
  • It is the best measure of growth of a population.

questions.text: In a population, the age-specific fertility rates (ASFR) are given for the following age groups: Age range Age-specific fertility rates (ASFR) Age-specific fertility rates (ASFR) per 1000 women 15-19 years 80 45 20-24 years 280 120 25-29 years 220 110 30-34 years 170 90 35-39 years 85 45 40-44 years 21 10 45-49 years 3 2 Calculate the Gross Reproductive Rate (GRR) for the age group of 25 years.
Which of the following best defines the total fertility rate (TFR)?

options.label: A
options.text: Total live births per 1000 women in a specific age group per year.

options.label: B
options.text: Average live births per 1000 women of reproductive age (15-49 years) per year.

options.label: C
options.text: Average number of children per woman based on current fertility rates throughout her reproductive life (15-49 years).

options.label: D
options.text: Number of live births in a given year divided by the mid-year population, multiplied by 1,000.

questions.correct_answer: C. Average number of children per woman based on current fertility rates throughout her reproductive life (15-49 years).

questions.text: A health research team is studying fertility patterns in two neighbouring urban regions. The team decides to use the general and age-specific fertility rates for their analysis. Which approach will provide a more detailed understanding of fertility behaviour when comparing fertility patterns between the two regions?

options.label: A
options.text: Live births per 1000 women of childbearing age, 15-49 years

options.label: C
options.text: Live births per 1000 women in specific age groups

options.label: D
options.text: Total number of births in the population

questions.correct_answer: C. Live births per 1000 women in specific age groups
questions.explanation:
General Fertility rate

Age-specific fertility rate (ASFR)

Definition

The total number of live births in an area in a year per 1000 women in the reproductive age group (15- 44 or 49 years). (Option A)

Number of live births in a year per 1000 women in any specific age group. (Option C)

Disadvantages and advantages

Disadvantage:

Not everyone in the reproductive age group is exposed to the risk of childbirth

Advantages:

  • Unlike crude birth rate(CBR), ASFR is unaffected by differences, changes in population age composition
  • It gives the fertility trends of a country.
  • ASFR is more useful than GFR in comparing:
    • Different populations
    • Sub-groups of the same population.
    • Measuring changes in fertility over time in the same population

questions.text: Which of the following best defines the crude birth rate?

options.label: A
options.text: Live births per 1,000 people in mid-year population per year

options.label: B
options.text: Live births per 1,000 people in annual population per year

options.label: C
options.text: Live births and stillbirths per 100,000 people in the mid-year population per year

options.label: D
options.text: Live births and stillbirths per 100,000 people in annual population per year

questions.correct_answer: A. Live births per 1,000 people in mid-year population per year
questions.explanation:
Crude birth rates

Crude death rates

Definition

Number of live births per 1000 estimated

mid-year population in a given year.

Number of deaths (from all causes) per

1000 estimated mid-year population in one year in a given place.

Statistics

India’s current CBR is 19.5/1000 mid-year population. (2020)

India’s current CDR is 6/1000 mid-year population. (2020)

Drawbacks

It gives a rough measure of fertility by giving birth rates, and not everyone in the population is exposed to childbirth.

Lack of comparability across communities with different age, sex, race, etc.

questions.text: In the graph of a demographic transition model given below, identify the following.

options.label: A
options.text: A- Death rate, B- Population, C- Birth rate, X- Late expanding

options.label: B
options.text: A- Birth rate, B- Death rate, C- Population, X- Late expanding

options.label: C
options.text: A- Death rate, B- Birth rate, C- Population, X- Early expanding

options.label: D
options.text: A- Birth rate, B- Death rate, C- Population, X- Early expanding

questions.correct_answer: B. A- Birth rate, B- Death rate, C- Population, X- Late expanding
questions.explanation:
Stages

Birth rate

Death rate

Population

High stationery

High

High

Population is stable

Early expanding

High

Starts declining

Population grows at faster rate.

  • Aka Demographic trap

Late expanding

Starts declining

Keeps declining

Population grows at slower rate (birth > death)

Low stationery

Low

Low

Stable population

Declining

Low

Lower

Population declines (death rate > birth rate)

questions.text: Which of the following is a positive mortality indicator?
A country has 40 million people under 15, 30 million aged 65 and over, and 150 million aged 15-64. What is the dependency ratio?
Which of the following are the implications of female deficit syndrome?

options.label: B
options.text: Bias towards males in population counts.

questions.explanation:

  • ↳ Sex Ratio : Number of females per 1000 males.

Implications of Low Sex Ratio : Indicates a preference for male children. questions.text: Match the following terms and definitions with Terms Definitions 1. Demographic Burden a) Period of decrease in the dependency ratio 2. Demographic Bonus b) Indicates a rise in the total dependency ratio 3. Demographic Window c) Increase in economic growth rate 4. Demographic Dividend d) Peak working-age population phase
Which of the following is NOT true regarding demographic gifts?

options.label: A
options.text: It occurs when there is a significant increase in the working-age population.

options.label: B
options.text: It involves a higher proportion of elderly individuals.

options.label: C
options.text: It leads to a demographic dividend for economic development.

options.label: D
options.text: It is associated with a decline in dependency ratios.

questions.correct_answer: B. It involves a higher proportion of elderly individuals.
questions.explanation:
Demographic Gift

Demographic Liability

The demographic gift occurs when the working-age population is high relative to dependents.

The higher proportion of elderly individuals refers to demographic liability.

Represents a potential demographic dividend due to a larger workforce contributing to economic growth.

Represents potential economic challenges due to increased dependency ratios and healthcare costs

Contributors include higher productivity, increased savings, and economic growth

Dependents include retirees, elderly individuals, and those requiring significant healthcare

questions.text: Population pyramid represents the age and sex composition of a population. All of the following statements about a Population Pyramid are false except?

options.label: A
options.text: A broad base and narrow apex indicate a high fertility rate and low life expectancy.

options.label: B
options.text: The width of the base of a population pyramid represents the elderly population.

options.label: C
options.text: They always have a symmetrical shape across all countries.

options.label: D
options.text: Population pyramids are static and do not change over time.

questions.correct_answer: A. A broad base and narrow apex indicate a high fertility rate and low life expectancy.

questions.text: Population and Vital statistics represent the demography of a population. Which of the following is not considered a vital statistic in demography?
questions.explanation:
Population statistics

Vital statistics
  • Population size
  • Sex ratio
  • Literacy rate
  • Dependency ratio
  • Population density
  • Birth rate
  • Death rate
  • Natural growth rate
  • Life expectancy at birth
  • Mortality rate
  • Fertility rate

questions.text: Assuming a population follows the Malthusian growth model and doubles in number in 20 years, what is its annual growth rate?
questions.explanation:
Time taken to double = 70 / Annual growth rate

Annual growth rate

Doubling time

If 1 %

70 years

If 0.5 %

140 years

If 2 %

35 years

If 1.5 %

50 years

questions.text: Demographic transition refers to a change of demographic parameters like birth rate and death rate along with the dynamic process of socio- economic scenario. Which of the following scenarios best describes the demographic trap of a country?

options.label: A
options.text: High birth rate (CBR) and declining death rate (CDR) lead to outpaced economic growth and resources.

options.label: B
options.text: Declining birth rate (CBR), which falls below the death rate (CDR), thus leading to shrinkage of the population.

options.label: C
options.text: High birth rate (CBR) and high death rate (CDR) leading to a stable population without growth

questions.correct_answer: A. High birth rate (CBR) and declining death rate (CDR) lead to outpaced economic growth and resources.

questions.text: Based on the demographic transition model, which transition phase does India belong to?
questions.explanation:
Stage

Countries

I - High stationery

India until 1920

II - Early expanding

African and south Asian countries

III - Late expanding

India

IV - Low stationary

Austria, Denmark, Sweden

V - Declining

Germany, Italy, United Kingdom, Japan

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with the term demographic gap?

options.label: A
options.text: People entering and people leaving the country

options.label: B
options.text: Crude birth rate and crude death rate

options.label: D
options.text: Age group of males and females

questions.correct_answer: B. Crude birth rate and crude death rate
questions.explanation:
Demographic gap = Crude birth rate - Crude death rate

Phases

Demographic gap

Explanation

1. High stationery

Minimum

Both birth and death rates are high, leading to minimal population growth.

2. Early expanding

Maximum

Death rates drop rapidly while birth rates remain high, causing a population explosion.

3. Late expanding

Narrowing or Contracting

Birth rates begin to decline and approach lower death rates, slowing population growth.

4. Low stationery

Minimum

Both birth and death rates are low and roughly equal, leading to a stable population size.

5. Declining

Negative

Birth rates fall below death rates, leading to population decline.
